input_data.title: 102 Minutes That Changed America
input_data.overview:
102 Minutes That Changed America is a 102-minute American television special documentary film that was produced by the History channel and premiered commercial-free on September 11, 2008, marking the seventh anniversary of the 2001 attacks. The film depicts, in virtually real time, the New York-based events of the attacks primarily using raw footage from mostly amateur citizen journalists. The documentary is accompanied by an 18-minute documentary short called I-Witness to 9/11, which features interviews with nine firsthand eyewitnesses who captured the footage on camera.

According to this film, most of the archival footage was in possession of the U.S. government but was released to History years after 9/11. The documentary film attracted 5.2 million viewers. The program aired on Channel 4 in the UK, France 3 in France, History Channel in Brazil on 7 September 2009, SBS6, in the Netherlands on 9 September 2009 and on ZDF in 2009 and 2010. A&E Television Networks, parent company of History, aired it across all of their cable networks on September 11, 2011 at 8:46 a.m. EDT, the exact time American Airlines Flight 11 crashed into 1 World Trade Center ten years earlier.

response.analytical_summary: 102 Minutes That Changed America is a documentary special that reconstructs the events of September 11, 2001, through raw footage captured primarily by citizen journalists. The program aims to provide a visceral and immediate experience of the attacks, recreating the unfolding tragedy in near real-time. It emphasizes the role of ordinary people documenting extraordinary events, highlighting the power of citizen journalism in historical record-keeping. The documentary’s impact lies in its ability to offer a uniquely personal and immediate perspective on a pivotal moment in American history, fostering reflection and remembrance.
response.spoiler_rich_plot_summary: The documentary meticulously recreates the events of September 11, 2001, beginning with the initial reports of the first plane striking the North Tower of the World Trade Center. It then follows the unfolding chaos as the second plane hits the South Tower, and the towers begin to collapse. The program interweaves amateur footage with news reports, showcasing the confusion and fear that gripped New York City and the nation. The documentary follows the events as they unfold, showing the reactions of bystanders, first responders, and those trapped in the towers. It concludes with the collapse of the World Trade Center and the subsequent search and rescue efforts, leaving a lasting impression of the day’s devastation and the resilience of the human spirit.
response.keyword_sentence: 102 Minutes That Changed America is a somber documentary that reconstructs the tragic events of September 11th through raw, amateur footage, offering a visceral and emotional remembrance of a pivotal moment in history.
